lexUnit.name: timid.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: lacking in courage or confidence.

sentence.text: ` Why are farmers so timid in this respect ? " asks Professor James .
Maybe it is they who are being too timid in their ideas and proposals .
When she meets other animals , walk on and ignore her -- as she is timid of strange people , I think this will overrule her aggression towards a strange dog , and she will catch up very quickly .
Prunella had nicely been trying to prise him out of it before they came , but she was timid of him .
The new puppy is very timid with strangers but now she is old enough to go out for walks , we have found she is growling at other dogs .
Nellie was not a bit shy or timid like I was , and I was attracted by her outspoken ways .
I always said that Halliwell was too timid by half .
Many riders we hear about seem unjustifiably timid about taking themselves and their horses off across the countryside .
She heard the timid knock on her door and sighed .
So its time to play the timid virgin ?
He saw Wycliffe and acknowledged him with a timid gesture .
` I love myself while being nervous and timid . "
Though she was usually timid , this accusation outraged Florrie .
I should have been as timid as the girl herself , if she had looked at me !
She 's sweet , pathologically timid and probably only about fifteen .
Agnes looked timid and I could hear the old servant weeping in the scullery .
